docs.lead_paragraph: INTERNATIONAL A3-8 Muslims May Be Ready To Attack Bosnian Serbs The Muslim-led Government in Sarajevo appears to be intensifying a clandestine program to arm and train its military, and senior NATO officials say it may already be able to mount a crushing offensive against the Bosnian Serbs. docs.lead_paragraph: CCA PRISON REALTY TRUST, Nashville, a real estate investment trust, bought the Torrance County Detention Center in New Mexico from Corrections Corp. of America for $38.5 million. RDM SPORTS GROUP INC., Atlanta, said its board planned to sell the assets of its Flexible Flyer Toys unit for $23 million to Hedstrom Corp., a company controlled by Hicks, Muse, Tate & Furst Inc. LIFE RE CORP., Stamford, Conn., a life and health reinsurance company, bought a 79 percent stake in AML Acquisition Co. of Jacksonville, Fla., a life insurance holding company, for $22.3 million, including the assumption of $9.8 million in debt.

docs.lead_paragraph: A Brooklyn judge has ruled that board members of cooperative apartment buildings can face criminal charges for actions by the board, a decision that has alarmed many volunteers who serve on co-op boards throughout the city. The case in which the ruling was made involves misdemeanor criminal charges filed against a co-op, and against several individual board members, after a boy fell out a window and died. The defendants are accused of violating the city law requiring window guards in apartments housing small children.

headline.main: Co-op Board Members Fret Over Ruling on Liability

docs.abstract: NYC Criminal Court, Brooklyn, Judge Kathryn M Smith rules that board members of cooperative apartment buildings can face criminal charges for actions by board, decision that has alarmed many volunteers who serve on co-op boards throughout city; case involves misdemeanor criminal charges against co-op and several individual board members in connection with boy falling out of window and dying; defendants are accused of violating city law requiring window guards in apartments housing small children (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: In a day packed with a half-dozen public events to promote good child care, Hillary Rodham Clinton demonstrated today that she had learned some lessons from the failure of her 1994 campaign to enact national health insurance. She told an audience in Miami that advocating a number of big changes at once can overwhelm people and that small, incremental changes were more realistic. And she spent the afternoon at the sprawling Marine base here in Virginia highlighting the commitment to child care of an important political ally -- the military, which runs the nation's largest child-care system. (At Quantico, child care costs $120 a week, with the Government paying half.)

headline.main: First Lady Is Low Key On Overhaul Of Child-Care

docs.abstract: Hillary Rodham Clinton appears at half-dozen public events in Miami, Fla, and Virginia to promote good child care (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Largely absent from Washington's policy battles since national health insurance died in 1994, Hillary Rodham Clinton embarked today on a campaign to improve child care for working parents, particularly for people moving off welfare and into jobs. She said one important first step could be setting up a national registry for child-care workers that would allow parents to check on employment histories.

headline.main: Hillary Clinton Begins Drive To Improve Care for Children

docs.abstract: Hillary Rodham Clinton begins campaign to improve child care for working parents, particularly for people moving off welfare and into jobs; proposes setting up national registry for child-care workers that would allow parents to check on employment histories; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: In the days after her 2-month-old son died, Tabitha Walrond wept openly in the dim hallways of her brick tenement in the Bronx, telling neighbors she so missed her gurgling baby that she could not eat or sleep. She called him ''an angel boy who brought love.'' And after he died at Bronx Lebanon Hospital Center on Aug. 27, she scribbled those words on the back of a tiny photograph of her black-haired son, Tyler.

headline.main: Mother Who May Have Fed Her Son Improperly Is Charged in His Death

docs.abstract: Tabitha Walrond is charged with criminally negligent homicide in connection with death of her 2-month-old son in their Bronx apartment on Aug 27; prosecutors say that Walrond failed to feed her son properly and to heed warnings that he was becoming sickly (M)
